column4: Guys quick question what is the difference between LTS and non LTS?
I can't seem to find any information on it and I would have thought version 7 would be supported longer than the 6.x branch...
LTS == Long Time Support. The LTS releases are guaranteed to be supported with security fixes etc. for a certain amount of time
So 7.x is newer then and will become LTS when 8.x comes out?
no, one of the 8.x releases will be LTS
(iirc)
most ubuntu releases aren't LTS
Right but one in the 7.x branch will be?
I assume the 7.x branch will go for a while then 8.x will come out once 7.x becomes stable and then 7.x will become LTS?
no, AFAIK LTS releases are LTS from the start. I don't think 7.x will ever be LTS.
Right, so is it work going 7.04 or 6.06?
worth*
for a office workstation or server, 6.06. For a home machine, 7.04.
7.04 is still "supported" with security updates - it's just that there's no guarantee as to how long such support will continue.
Well I am going to try ubuntu on the server I am building up it was running Debian, thought I'd give it a shot, so 6.06 then?
yeah, go for 6.06 if you're planning on doing something important with your server
I still run 6.06 on my home fileserver (havn't bothered to upgrade) and it works fine
heh
At least I can download it at 1.4MB/s :|
It'll mainly be used for VMware
Not sure if it's going to be any better than Debian for it
probably won't be, tbh. Ubuntu SEvr is basically identical to Debian.
